title: squared sans style
content:
I’ve noticed a trend in the last few years of sans faces that have a very clean contemporary look with flattened curves. Prime exampels are [Stainless](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122055925/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=stainless&x=0&y=0) and [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/). What was the originating face, and does anyone have other notable examples?

 [‹ segmented LCD numeral and text displays: Changed at all in 50 years?](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122055925/http:/www.typophile.com/node/48051 "Go to previous forum topic") [Modestly priced workhorses ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122055925/http:/www.typophile.com/node/48311 "Go to next forum topic")
author: nitrospectide

comments.content:
The earliest example I can think of in this category is Microgramma/Eurostile, though Bank Gothic and possibly condensed versions of other sans faces might have preceded it. In fact, I’m fairly certain there are other squarish sans faces from further back. I just don’t know them well enough.

One of my own early efforts, [Bernur,](http://web.archive.org/web/20081122055925/http:/www.1001fonts.com/font_details.html?font_id=2206) probably fits in this category too.

Don’t most flattened curves go back to the super-ellipse of Piet Hein?

. . .  
Bert Vanderveen BNO
